content:
Thunderbird is an email client - a program you download onto your computer. It is not a server.

You create mail account - one for each email address. Thunderbird then accesses server and downloads email into the mail account, so you can have emails being downloaded from various servers and view them all in one place. Thunderbird has many other features too numerous to mention eg: Calendar. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-GB/features/

Thunderbird is free program to download, but it does rely on people making donations so the product can be maintained. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ https://www.thunderbird.net/en-GB/about/ https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/thunderbird/install-migrate-and-update https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/thunderbird/calendar https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/thunderbird/privacy-and-security-settings https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/115.0/whatsnew/
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: Toad-Hall

content: Toad-Hall I figured it out. I had installed an addon called Thunderbird Conversations. Helpful with multiple correspondents in the email chain. However, it has a column called "between" which referenced which correspondents were involved in each email within the conversation. Really very helpful, however, it seems it was this "between" column that was causing the printing issues. TB always wanted to restore this column even after removing it and a restart. In the the Thunderbird Conversations settings there is a check box that can override TB and completely remove the "between" column and then printing worked fine. Who would have guessed. Thanks for you help, as your idea of using the trouble shooting gave me the idea to trouble shoot the addons by turning them all off and then reactivating one by one. Bob

content:
To get the 'Print Preview' to work the email must be opened and have focus, it's not possible to do this with more than one email.

Old versions used to open email in background to access data. Some not so savvy people thought 'Print Preview' offered a more secure method of reading emails without opening them, not realising how you could see contents without opening them. The emails were opened in the background.

Then Firefox altered printing and so did Thunderbird as a certain amount of code is shared. The old opening in background ceased and now email must be selected and opened and have focus.

This then opens the 'Print Preview' window allowing you to make any necessary alterations.

For multiple: IF you select top level email of a collapsed thread so it shows the X number of messages in Message Pane Then right click on highlighted item in list and select 'Print'....

It does not open the 'Print Preview' window, but it should open the 'Print' window where you can select the name of printer.

I just tested this on an email which has 3 emails in thread (collapsed) and got the Print dialogue window. I selected printer and clicked Print

Now I do not need to actually print them and printer is turned off, so I accessed the 'Printer ' documents to see queue and there's 3 emails with same subject and slightly different sizes which match the ones in Message List. So it would have printed all three if printer was turned on.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Hi ~ Experimented again. FROM 'INBOX' - SELECTING 'MOVE TO' TO A LOCAL FOLDERS SUBFOLDER ~ selected email disappears from Inbox and appears in selected subfolder.

FROM 'SENT' ~ SELECTING 'MOVE TO' TO A LOCAL FOLDERS SUBFOLDER ~ selected email disappears from Sent and appears in selected subfolder.

After doing both of above, I closed Thunderbird, and reopened. The email which I moved from "SENT" WAS NOT THERE, AND IT STILL APPEARED IN THE SELECTED SUBFOLDER I MOVED IT TO.

So it appears all is back to normal now???? It was not doing this for several days earlier.....actually was frustrating because when I did move an email from the "Sent" folder to a subfolder, it moved....but then reappeared. And then I made several attempts at the same thing again.....so with each attempt, the same email accumulated several times in the subfolder but kept reappearing in the "Sent" folder. This was only happening when trying to use the "Move To" function from the SENT folder.

So again...all worked as it was supposed to. Not sure why it's now OK? But all appears to be!

Thank you for your help.
creator: jgamble2

content:
You would expect the 'Move to' to move the email into the selected Local Folders folder and the action would auto delete email off server as email had been removed from the account.

In your case, it removed email from imap folder, but it did not move/delete email off the server, so when imap folder synched with server folder it reappeared.

When you used the 'Move to' - did the email in 'Local Folders' subfolder remain in that folder?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I knew I'd mess this up.....forgot to add....when you use the "Copy To" function.....you have to go back to the SENT folder, of course, and delete those emails from the SENT folder. They don't disappear obviously.

Sorry...anyway. Thanks.
creator: jgamble2

content:
Thanks for your response. I tried your suggestion, and this is the result: When I go to my "Sent" folder of emails, I can click on an email, then click "Move To" and then select the subfolder I want to move it to. It moves successfully, and it temporarily "disappears" from the "Sent" listing. However, when I shut down Thunderbird, and then reopen it, the same email still appears in my "Sent" folder of emails. So it "moves" but it doesn't disappear permanently from the "Sent" folder~~which I assumed was the intent of that function.

So when I tried your suggestion tonight....instead of choosing the "Move To" task, I clicked on the "Copy To" command....then selected the subfolder I wanted the email to be copied to. The email then appears in the new subfolder and apparently REMAINS GONE from the "Sent" folder. I closed down Thunderbird and reopened it...and apparently, THIS works. So I guess the difference is the "Move To" function as opposed to the "Copy To" function.....maybe it's me. I just assumed that if I "moved" an email from one folder to another, the point was that it would disappear from the original folder and then remain housed in the new subfolder. But apparently that is not the case when using the "Move To" command. It only works with the "Copy To" function....which seems entirely backward to me....but guess I'll now use the "Copy To" command to perform this task from now on.

Thanks for your comment and response. I truly assumed that "Move To" was the correct task for this....that it would literally move from one area to another. But apparently that only works with the "Copy To" function. Again, seems contradictory to me.....but will continue to try to work with this function in this "new way."

Thx again.
creator: jgamble2

content:
geof.hovell said
you ask post image....sorry HOW

Get the problem 'Write' window displaying on desktop so we can see all the top toolbar area. If you make window maximise then it covers all desktop, so not showing anything else. Then right click in toolbar area to open the 'Customise'

So now we can see both the Write toolbar area and what is displaying as options in that Customise area.

  • On keyboard, press the 'Prt Scr' key and this auto creates an image of desktop stored to clipboard.
  • Open a simple image program like 'Paint'
  • Use 'Ctrl+V' keys and an image of the desktop will auto get pasted into Paint.
  • File > Save as > jpeg picture
  • Choose where to save it eg: desktop
  • Give it name eg: Write-no-send
  • click on 'Save'
  • In this forum question, in a 'Post a Reply' text area type some text that is relevant.
  • Below the text area is 'Add images' - click on 'Browse' button
  • locate and select the jpg image stored on desktop
  • click on 'Open'

it gets uploaded as a thumbnail image. click on 'Post Reply' button

see image below as guide.

content:
MinimalTech said
Very helpful david! But instead of this, because these folders are about 20GB, is there a way to import them through the PST I already have in my hands? Can I import these folders from the PST to the local folders?

Yes, load the PST into Outlook and then use the importer in Thunderbird to import from Outlook. Or just run the importer from the tools menu on your existing outlook installation.

What Thunderbird can do it talk to outlook, it can not do anything at all with a PST file.

And, if the answer is yes, how can I import anything to the local folders?

You are holding a proprietary formatted file. While Microsoft have published a number of descriptions of the file formats used in various versions of the PST over the years, Thunderbird has never been able to read any of those formats. There has never been a commitment of sufficient resources to write import code for that file format as there is functional code for the import from Outlook. This is even less important as most folk now use IMAP and the data is generally available from the web unless the person is already using a desktop mail client like outlook.

The internet is essentially full of converters to convert PST files into mbox files (google is your friend here) which Thunderbird uses natively. They vary in cost and quality and as I am not at all involved with using any of them I can not offer advice as to one over another.

Once your data is in a non proprietary format you can either place the files in the local folders directory in Thunderbird profile (without a file extension) or use the import export tools add-on to import the mbox files for you. https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

As sfhowes says mailstore home may read these files, but it is not Thunderbird. It is also a windows only solution (so no access from your Android or Apple phone) to email archiving that is free for home use. I mention the license requirement for free home use only as you mention your requirement include your job which to me implies bushiness use.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: I think you can import pst files to MailStore Home, and either keep them there as an archive, or export them to eml or mbox format from MSH, which can then be easily imported to TB Local Folders.

content: To me, that seems a lot of work, but it's doable. I am no PST guru, but if you do a web search for 'thunderbird pst import' there are many websites with step-by-step instructions. Good luck.

content:
Your choice is IMAP or POP and there is an addon for Microsoft Exchange

IMAP is no slower on most occasions that POP once the initial syncronisation of the folders and mail occurs. At least it is not slower for those of us that do not use antivirus programs that scan incoming mail and reduce the speed of downloads to about 50% of normal in their process.

content:
In the "see also" section I found my solution: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1420329 This solution explains how to migrate Thunderbird profile from snap to Flatpak.

1 Copy your profile info to the Flatpak data zone:

  • from /home/.Thunderbird/
  • to /home/.var/app/org.mozilla.Thunderbird/cache/thunderbird

2 launch Thunderbird with option -P

  • flatpak run org.mozilla.Thunderbird -P
  • create new profile and then select the newly created profile in the Flatpak
